title: 107_hr4668
content: The "Renewable Fuel Equity Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes the expansion of renewable resources credit. The "Renewable Fuel Equity Act" expands the renewable resources credit by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include geothermal energy, solar energy, incremental hydropower, and biomass (other than closed-loop biomass) as qualified energy resources. Additionally, the Act extends and modifies the placed-in-service rules for biomass facilities. The "Renewable Fuel Equity Act" expands the renewable resources credit to include geothermal energy, solar energy, incremental hydropower, and biomass. It also extends and modifies the placed-in-service rules for biomass facilities using closed-loop biomass for electricity production. The Act defines biomass as solid, nonhazardous, cellulosic waste material derived from forest-related resources, including mill residues, precommercial thinnings, slash, brush, solid wood waste materials, and agriculture sources. The code is amended to include special rules for biomass facilities, such as the 10-year period starting from the enactment date, exemption from certain provisions for facilities in service before 1997, and treating lessees as owners for tax purposes. The tax code is amended to include geothermal facilities as qualified facilities for tax purposes, whether placed in service before or after December 31, 2001, with incremental geothermal production being eligible for tax benefits. The tax code now includes geothermal facilities as qualified for tax benefits, allowing incremental geothermal production to be eligible for tax incentives. Solar energy facilities and incremental hydropower facilities also qualify for tax credits under specific conditions. The tax code now includes incremental hydropower facilities as qualified for tax benefits, allowing additional generation from increased efficiency or new capacity at non-Federal hydroelectric projects to be eligible for tax incentives. Incremental geothermal production refers to the excess electricity generated from a geothermal facility compared to the average production over the previous seven years, excluding the highest and lowest years. This definition applies to specific facilities outlined in subsection (c)(3)(E)(ii) of the tax code. The tax code amendment in subsection (c)(3)(E)(ii) reduces the calculated amount each year for geothermal facilities in service for seven years or longer, with a cumulative cap of 30 percent. This amendment does not apply to qualified facilities eligible for other credits. Amended section 48(a)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code to allow for an increased credit for certain equipment used to produce electricity from a qualified facility. The amendment allows for a 20 percent energy percentage for energy property with less than 1 megawatt capacity placed in service before January 1, 2007. Effective date for the amendments is after December 31, 2001.
